{{Infobox member of the Knesset |image = File:Ambassador Shapiro's trip to BeerSheba (17782837459) (cropped).jpg |birth_date = {{birth date and age|1961|1|1|df=y}} |birth_place = [[Na'an]], [[Israel]] |death_date = |death_place = |Knesset(s) = [[Israeli legislative election, 2013|19]], [[Israeli legislative election, 2015|20]] |party1 = [[Israeli Labor Party|Labor Party]] |partyyears1 = 2013–2015 |party2 = [[Zionist Union]] |partyyears2 = 2015–2017 }}
'''Erel Margalit''' ({{lang-he|אראל מרגלית}}; born 1 January 1961) is an [[Israel]]i politician and a high-tech and social entrepreneur. He served as a member of the [[Knesset]] on behalf of the [[Israeli Labor Party|Labor Party]] between 2015 and 2017. Previously, he was the founder and managing partner of the [[Jerusalem]]-based [[Venture capital in Israel|venture capital]] firm [[Jerusalem Venture Partners| Jerusalem Venture Partners (JVP)]]. In 2005, '' [[Forbes]] '' international business magazine selected Margalit as the top-ranking non-American venture capitalist on its prestigious "Midas (The Golden Touch) List.” <ref>{{cite web|title=Forbes|url=https://www.forbes.com/finance/lists/99/2005/LIR.jhtml?passListId=99&passYear=2005&passListType=Person&uniqueId=BLMA&datatype=Person|work=The Midas List|publisher=Forbes Publishing|accessdate=May 2, 2011}}</ref> In 2010, ''[[The Marker|The Marker Magazine]]'' named him the best venture capitalist in Israel.<ref>{{cite news|title=מלך האקזיטים: אראל מרגלית - איש ההון סיכון בעל מגע הזהב|url=http://www.themarker.com/hitech/1.576997|accessdate=May 2, 2011|newspaper=The Marker}}</ref> Margalit is a founder of the Avoda Now movement in 2011 which aimed to rehabilitate the Labour Party following the split by Ehud Barak and the creation of [[Independence (Israeli political party)|HaAtzma'ut Party]]. In 2013, Margalit was elected to the [[List of members of the nineteenth Knesset|19th Knesset]] as a representative of the Labor party.<ref name="Meet the MK:Erel Margalit">[http://www.jpost.com/Features/InThespotlight/Article.aspx?id=302413 Meet the MK:Erel Margalit]</ref> Margalit currently serves as a member of the prestigious Finance Committee and the Science and Technology Committee. He chairs the Parliamentary Task Forces for Economic Development in the North and the Negev, Cyber Protection and Combating Living Costs in Israel, and co-chairs the Parliamentary Task Force for Small and Medium Businesses, Integrating the Ultra-Orthodox in the High-Tech Sector, Employment for the Arab-Israeli Sector, 40+ Employment, and the Task Force for the City of Jerusalem.
== Biography == Erel Margalit was born in kibbutz [[Na'an]], the eldest of three siblings. His father, Itzik Margalit, was an officer in the IDF [[Armored Corps (Israel)|Armored Corps]] and one of the founders of moshav [[Kfar Haim]], and his mother, Mickey, was a founding member of moshav [[Avihayil]]. On his mother's side, he is descended from Jews who immigrated to what was then Ottoman Palestine from [[Bulgaria]] in the 19th century, prior to the beginning of the [[First Aliyah]]. He is a descendant of Shmuel Tagir, one of the founders of [[Tel Aviv]].
In 1969, when Margalit was eight years old, the family was sent on a mission to [[Detroit]], [[Michigan]] where his father was head of a local Hebrew school.<ref name="Meet the MK:Erel Margalit"/> While in high school in Michigan, Erel became a point-guard on a local basketball team. After returning to Israel in 1971, the family settled in [[Karmiel]] before moving to [[Jerusalem]]. He attended Rene Cassin High School and continued to play basketball there. Recognition of his talent led to an offer to join the Israeli youth team, but he declined in favor of serving in an [[Israel Defense Forces|IDF]] combat unit.<ref>{{cite news|last=Prince-Gibson|first=Eetta|title=Erel Margalit's powerful visions|url=http://www.israel21c.org/culture/erel-margalit-s-powerful-visions|accessdate=May 2, 2011|newspaper=Israel21C|date=May 2, 2011}}</ref> He served in the [[Golani Brigade]]'s ''"Orev"'' unit as an operations officer, reaching the rank of sergeant major. As a reservist in 1982, he fought in the [[1982 Lebanon War|First Lebanon War]] with the IDF's airborne anti-tank division.
Margalit studied philosophy and English literature at the [[Hebrew University of Jerusalem]], where he met his future wife. In 1985 Margalit moved to New York to attend [[Columbia University]] where he continued towards a doctorate in philosophy and logic. During his studies he was exposed to [[Michael Porter]]'s "The Competitive Advantage of Nations," which influenced his doctoral dissertation on the subject, "The Entrepreneur as a Leader in the Historical Process."<ref>{{cite web|title=Israeli Business Forum of New York|url=http://www.israelibusinessforum.org/content/events/past_events/04-08-17erel_margalit.html|work=Speaker: Erel N. Margalit — Founder & Managing Partner, Jerusalem Venture Partners (JVP)|accessdate=May 2, 2011}}</ref> which he completed in 2007.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://engineering.columbia.edu/web/newsletterarchive/spring08/feature2.php |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2012-11-08 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100623054811/http://engineering.columbia.edu/web/newsletterarchive/spring08/feature2.php |archivedate=2010-06-23 |df= }}</ref>
In response to the [[First Intifada]] and the anti-Israel activities on American campuses, Margalit organized a dialogue group between Israeli and Arab students. Together with other Israeli doctoral students, among them [[Yossi Dahan]] and [[Yossi Bachar]], he established groups on eight leading campuses.
Margalit is married to Debbie and has three daughters: Tair, Eden, and Maya.<ref>{{cite web|title=Israeli Business Forum|url=http://www.israelibusinessforum.org/content/events/past_events/10-03-23-Margalit.html|work=PIONEERING ISRAEL'S NEW SOCIAL-ECONOMIC ERA:The Role of the Creative Class|accessdate=May 2, 2011}}</ref>
== Career ==
=== Jerusalem Development Authority === Returning to Israel in 1990, Margalit began to work at the [[Jerusalem Development Authority]] under Uzi Wexler, promoting business development and technological entrepreneurship in Jerusalem. During this time, he worked closely with [[Teddy Kollek]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Giving Wisely|url=http://www.givingwisely.org.il/?page_id=3446&amuta=580394872|work=Jerusalem Venture Partners (JVP) Community}}</ref> He also worked in cooperation with American governors, among them [[Mario Cuomo]] of [[New York (state)|New York]], [[Pete Wilson]] of [[California]], [[James Florio]] of [[New Jersey]] and [[Rodney Wallace (Massachusetts)|Rodney Wallace]] of Massachusetts. Margalit helped to attract dozens of technology companies to Jerusalem with the aim of turning the city into a high-tech capital for Israel. In three years, he succeeded in bringing in 70 large technology companies, including [[Digital data|Digital]] and [[IBM]]. In June 1994, Margalit left the JDA and embarked on an independent career.<ref>{{cite news|last=Prince-Gibson|first=Eetta|title=Erel Margalit's powerful visions|url=http://www.israel21c.org/culture/erel-margalit-s-powerful-visions|accessdate=May 2, 2011|newspaper=Israel21C}}</ref>
=== Jerusalem Venture Partners (JVP) === [[File:madpis.jpg|thumb|right|250px|JVP Media Quarter in Jerusalem]] In 1993, Erel Margalit founded the [[Jerusalem Venture Partners|JVP]] venture capital fund. He created a new model that integrated an active management approach with a strategy of forming an international market. Under his leadership, JVP has been instrumental in building dozens of high-tech startups into global corporations operating in Israel, the United States, Europe and Asia. Under his leadership, the JVP Fund currently runs investments of approximately 850 million dollars in eight funds, and specializes in investments in media, internet, mobile telephony, advertising and gaming industries. Erel has personally led seventeen successful exits, including the sale of Chromatis Networks, to [[Lucent| Lucent Technologies]] in 2000 for $4.82 billion, the second highest amount ever paid to an Israel company after Mobileye, sold to Intel in 2017 for $15.3 billion, and the IPO of [[QlikTech|Qlik Technologies]], which as of April 2011 was valued at over $2 billion.<ref>{{cite web|title=JVP Venture Capital|url=http://www.jvpvc.com/funds-about|work=About|accessdate=May 2, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=CrunchBase|url=http://www.crunchbase.com/person/erel-n-margalit|work=Erel N. Margalit|publisher=TechCrunch|accessdate=May 2, 2011}}</ref>
Board Positions: Anyclip- Co-founder & Chairman 2018; Initial investment was in early 2007 CyberArk (NASDAQ: CYBR) - Chairman – Initial investment 2002, $540M IPO in 2014, sold position for $1.7B between 2014-2016 QlikTech (NASDAQ:QLIK)- Board Member – Initial investment in 2004, $770M IPO in 2010, sold position in 2012 for $2.5B Chromatis- Board Member – Initial investment 1998, Sold to Lucent in 2000 for $4.9B Netro- Investor – Initial Investment 1994, $351M IPO in 1999, sold position for $5.5B Cogent Communications (NASDAQ: CCOI)- Board Member – Initial investment 2000, $260M IPO in 2007, valued today at $2B Cyoptics- Chairman – Initial investment 1999, Sold to Avago in 2013, $440M Precise- Board Member – Initial investment 1996, IPO 2000 sold position for $770M Scorpio- Investor – Initial investment 1995, Sold to US Robotics in 1996 Fundtech- Investor – Initial investment 1995, IPO March 1998 Paradigm Geophysical- board member – Initial investment in 1995, IPO 1998
=== The Media Quarter ===
In 2006, Erel Margalit formed and developed the new Media Quarter in and around the historical train station compound in Jerusalem. The Media Quarter, JVP Media Labs, a technological incubator, and The Lab, an arts incubator for Jerusalem performing artists, operate side by side. Currently over 300 young employees work in the Media Quarter, including engineers, artists, authors, filmmakers, and cultural figures. The Media Quarter has become one of the most innovative cultural and business scenes in Israel.<ref>{{cite web|title=JVP Venture Capital|url=http://www.jvpvc.com/about-the-media-quarter|work=About the Media Quarter|accessdate=May 2, 2011}}</ref>
== Social entrepreneurship ==
=== In the Community ''(Bakehila)'' === In 2002, Marglit founded the social organization '''Bakehila''' ('''בקהילה''' "In the Community" in Hebrew) as a means of reducing the socio-economic gap affecting disadvantaged children in Jerusalem. Bakehila runs [http://bakehila.wix.com/english#!programs/ci93 '''educational programs'''] in lower socioeconomic neighborhoods of Jerusalem with the goal of raising the students' academic achievements, and promoting the children's personal and interpersonal growth. Thousands of students from Jerusalem have attended the program during its first eight years.<ref name="about">{{cite web|publisher=JVP Venture Capital|url=http://www.jvpvc.com/community-about|title=About|accessdate=May 2, 2011}}</ref> In 2012, ''Bakehila'' opened an educational enrichment center in the Arab neighborhood of [[Beit Safafa]].<ref>[http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P1-201573198.html Beit Safafa education center dedicated]</ref>
=== The Lab ''(Hama'abada)'' === Following the events of the [[Second Intifada]] and the massive departure of young artists from Jerusalem, Erel Margalit created The Lab ''(Hama'abada)'' to keep and attract young artists in Israel's capital. The Lab provides support and assistance to these artists, providing venues for young Israelis to create, perform, and receive feedback on their work.<ref name="about" />
== Political activism ==
=== 2005 elections === During the 2005 election campaign, Margalit was one of the first businessmen to support [[Amir Peretz]] in the general elections. He joined the Labor Party and expressed his support of Peretz's social agenda. Margalit promoted his vision of economic growth whereby the [[Haredi Judaism#Israel|ultra-Orthodox]] and [[Arab citizens of Israel|Arab]] populations would be integrated in the labor market in Israel, thus taking them out of poverty and alleviating pressure on the middle classes. In addition, Margalit presented a plan for bringing the communities of Israel's geographic periphery closer to the center of the country, both economically and socially.<ref>{{cite web|last=Andromidas|first=Dean|title=Lebanon Wire|url=http://www.lebanonwire.com/1105/05113001EIB.asp|work=Political Upset in Israel: Labor Leader To Follow Rabin}}</ref>
=== Avoda Now Movement === Since his initial support of the Labor Party, Margalit grew disillusioned with the direction of the party and its leadership. On January 17, 2011, the Chairman of the Labor Party, [[Ehud Barak]], announced his resignation from the Labor Party and the establishment of a new party – "[[Atzmaut]]" (Independence Party).<ref>{{cite news|url=https://nypost.com/2011/01/18/barak-dumps-labor/ |title=Barak dumps Labor|author=Post Staff Report|work=[[New York Post]] |date=January 18, 2011}}</ref> Two days after this announcement Margalit helped to found the "Avoda Now" movement together with prominent members of Israel's business, technology, and cultural community, calling for a revival of the Labor Party. The movement launched a public campaign calling the people to join the Labor party lines; with the aim of renewing its institutions, restoring its social values, and choosing a new, dynamic leadership.<ref>{{cite web|title=PR Newswire|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2011/04/27/idUS272092+27-Apr-2011+PRN20110427|work=Erel Margalit Announces His Candidacy to Lead the Labor Party|publisher=Reuters|accessdate=May 2, 2011}}</ref>
On April 27, 2011, saying he could "no longer watch from the sidelines as the political situation in Israel deteriorates", Margalit announced his intention to run for the chairmanship of Israel's Labor Party.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2011/04/27/idUS272092+27-Apr-2011+PRN20110427|title=Erel Margalit Announces His Candidacy to Lead the Labor Party|publisher=Reuters|accessdate=May 2, 2011}}</ref>
=== In the Knesset === On 5 February 2013 Margalit became a Member of the Israeli Knesset<ref>http://www.erel.org.il/?p=2555</ref> and currently serves as a member of the prestigious Finance Committee and the Science and Technology Committee. He has been called the richest member of the Knesset.<ref>[http://www.jpost.com/Israel-News/Politics-And-Diplomacy/Erel-Margalit-is-not-Israels-Donald-Trump-456428 ''Jerusalem Post'', June 10, 2016]</ref> Margalit was especially active in the 2013 budget discussions criticizing its lack of economic growth engines (See {{YouTube|Nqsj4p1I6wU}}), and called to cancel the bi-yearly budget.<ref>http://www.themarker.com/news/politics/1.1938535</ref> He also led the Opposition on the discussions of the "HARIKUZIUT" bill, aimed to target the over-concentration and centralization in the Israeli economy.<ref>http://www.themarker.com/news/politics/1.2047565</ref><ref>http://www.themarker.com/news/politics/1.2049683</ref> Margalit chairs the Parliamentary Task Forces for Economic Development in the North and the Negev,<ref>http://www.local.co.il/haifa/106691/article.htm</ref> Civilian Cyber Protection and Combating Living Costs in Israel, and co-chairs the Parliamentary Task Force for Small and Medium Businesses, Integrating the Ultra-Orthodox in the High-Tech Sector, Employment for the Arab-Israeli Sector, 40+ Employment {{YouTube|uU_p30oKdEI}}, and the Task Force for the City of Jerusalem where he often criticizes the Israeli Government's policy of worrying about Jerusalem's borders but ignoring its content and neglecting its poor economic status.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.kibbutz.org.il/politit-takam/meida/knesset/130512_margalit.htm?nojump |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2013-11-20 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140114064001/http://www.kibbutz.org.il/politit-takam/meida/knesset/130512_margalit.htm?nojump |archivedate=2014-01-14 |df= }}</ref>
In the [[Israeli Labor Party leadership election, 2013|2013 Labor Party leadership election]] Margalit announced his support for the candidacy of MK [[Isaac Herzog]] for chairman.<ref>http://www.jdn.co.il/news/255341</ref><ref>http://www.al-monitor.com/pulse/iw/contents/articles/originals/2013/11/labor-party-shelly-yachimovich-erel-margalit-isaac-herzog.html</ref> Margalit was re-elected to the Knesset in the [[Israeli legislative election, 2015|2015 elections]]. In 2017 he contested the Labor Party leadership election, but was knocked out in the first round of voting. He subsequently resigned from the Knesset in October 2017 and was replaced by [[Leah Fadida]].<ref name=TOI>[https://www.timesofisrael.com/labor-mk-margalit-quits-knesset-in-second-party-resignation-in-week/ Labor MK Margalit quits Knesset, in second party resignation in week] Times of Israel, 3 October 2017</ref>

'''Francesco Gaetano Caltagirone''' ({{IPA-it|franˈtʃesko ɡa.eˈtaːno kaltadʒiˈroːne}}; born 1943) is an [[Italy|Italian]] businessman. He controls the holding company [[Caltagirone S.p.A.]] with interests in cement manufacturing, real estate, construction and publishing (with [[Caltagirone Editore]]).
As of 2015, Caltagirone was ranked number #894 on the 2015 ''Forbes'' billionaire list and #19 in Italy, with an estimated net worth of $2.1 billion.<ref>{{cite web |url= https://www.forbes.com/profile/francesco-gaetano-caltagirone/?list=billionaires |title= Billionaires (2015): #894 Francesco Gaetano Caltagirone |work= Forbes |date= February 2015 |quote= Net worth: $2.1 billion}}</ref>
==Biography== Francesco Gaetano Caltagirone was born in [[Rome]] into a large family composed almost entirely of manufacturers. His grandfather constructed the first buildings in [[Palermo]] in the last decades of the 1800s.
While studying at the faculty of engineering in Rome, Caltagirone and his brothers Edoardo Francesco Caltagirone and Leonardo Francesco Caltagirone resumed the family business that had been interrupted in the forties because of the sudden death of their father. With the inherited capital, the brothers started the company together with their cousin Gaetano Caltagirone, an architect already working as a manufacturer.
Francesco Gaetano Caltagirone became a partner in the company. Since then the group (today known as the Caltagirone Group or Caltagirone S.p.A) has constructed approximately 200 real estate complexes, composed of nearly 800 buildings with a total area of close to 3.3 million square metres and a value of €15 billion.
In the seventies the equity balance between Francesco Gaetano Caltagirone and his cousin Gaetano Caltagirone was changed, and Francesco Gaetano Caltagirone became part of the majority shareholders – on an equal footing with his brother Edoardo Francesco Caltagirone.
In 1984 he took over [[Vianini Lavori]] S.p.A. – now part of the Caltagirone Group – which operates worldwide in the field of large infrastructure project. He became president of the company. After a complete industrial restructuring, he carried out the listing of the two subsidiaries, Vianini Lavori S.p.A Industry and [[Vianini Industria]] S.p.A.
[[File:Il Presidente Francesco Gaetano Caltagirone alla festa di restyling de "Il Messaggero"..jpg|thumb|right|President Francesco Gaetano Caltagirone at the “Restyling Party” for the ''[[Il Messaggero]]'' newspaper, held in Milan in December 2012]] [[File:Francesco Gaetano Caltagirone al programma Otto e Mezzo di Lilly Gruber 004.png|thumb|right|President Francesco Gaetano Caltagirone interviewed at Lilly Gruber's television program ''Otto e Mezzo'' on La7 channel]]
In 1992 he took over [[Cementir]] S.p.A, the fourth biggest Italian company in the cement industry, acquired by IRI ([[Istituto per la Ricostruzione Industriale]]) through a public auction. In a few years, under the guidance of his son Francesco Caltagirone Jr., Cementir S.p.A became a multinational company with significant presence in Scandinavia, Turkey and the Far East. About 80% of the turnover is produced outside Italy.
In the mid-nineties he assumed full control of the Caltagirone Group joining his shares with those of his cousin Gaetano Caltagirone in the company Finanziaria Italia. Francesco Gaetano Caltagirone holds approximately 70% of Finanziaria Italia, which controls about 51% of Caltagirone S.p.A.
In 1996 he acquired the Roman newspaper ''[[Il Messaggero]]'' from the Montedison Group, and the following year two local newspapers from private investors: ''[[Il Mattino]]'' based in [[Naples]] and ''[[Il Corriere Adriatico]]'' based in [[Ancona]].
Since 2000 all publishing and new media have been clustered in the [[Caltagirone Editore]] publishing group – the fifth biggest group in Italy. In 2006 he acquired the majority stake in the newspaper ''[[Il Gazzettino]]'' based in [[Venice]].
Francesco Gaetano Caltagirone is a member of the Executive Committee of [[Confindustria]]<ref>{{cite web |website=ansa.it |url=http://www.ansa.it/web/notizie/rubriche/economia/2013/05/22/Confindustria-Caltagirone-giunta_8749930.html |title=Confindustria: Caltagirone in giunta |publisher=Ansa |date=22 May 2013 |accessdate=10 December 2013 }}</ref> and the Committee of the President of the Italian Federation of Newspaper Publishers,<ref>{{cite web |website=fieg.it |url=http://www.fieg.it/salastampa_item.asp?sta_id=713&language=en |title=FIEG: Rinnovate le cariche sociali per il biennio 2012 – 2014 |publisher=Federazione italiana editori giornali |date=11 June 2012 |accessdate=11 December 2013}}</ref> and he is a director of the Auditorium [[Parco della Musica]] of Rome.<ref>{{cite web |website=http://roma.corriere.it/roma/notizie/cronaca/11_maggio_19/cda-auditorium-nomine-190680548742.shtml |title=Auditorium nomine ai vertici. Alemanno conferma Fuortes |publisher=Corriere della Sera |date=19 May 2011 |accessdate=11 December 2013}}</ref>
In 2006 he was appointed a Knight of the [[Order of Merit for Labour]]. In the same year he became vice-president of [[Banca Monte dei Paschi di Siena]]. Until early 2012, when he liquidated his share completely, he was the second largest shareholder and the most important private individual shareholder. In 2007 he was appointed Director of [[Assicurazioni Generali]] S.p.A, of which he was appointed Vice President in April 2010.<ref>{{cite web |website=fieg.it |url=http://www.fieg.it/Generali-Group/Governance/corporate-bodies/members-of-the-board-of-directors/Vice-Chairman-Francesco-Gaetano-Caltagirone/ |title=Francesco Gaetano Caltagirone |publisher=Assicurazioni Generali S.p.A. |date=22 May 2013 |accessdate=10 December 2013}}</ref>
He is married to Luisa Farinon (the sister of former TV presenter [[Gabriella Farinon|Gabriella]]) and has three children: Francesco Jr., Alessandro and Azzurra,<ref>{{cite web |website=http://cinquantamila.corriere.it/storyTellerThread.php?threadId=CALTAGIRONE+Francesco+Gaetano |title=Caltagirone Francesco Gaetano |publisher=Corriere della Sera |date=5 October 2008 |accessdate=10 December 2013 }}</ref> the wife of the Italian politician [[Pier Ferdinando Casini]].

The '''Freedom to Speak Up Review''' was a review into [[whistleblowing]] in the [[NHS in England]]. It was announced on 24 June 2014 and it was chaired by [[Robert Francis (barrister)|Sir Robert Francis]].<ref>Sophie Borland Daily Mail (25 June 2014) [http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2668566/NHS-gripped-culture-fear-Inquiry-whistleblowing-set-barrister-investigated-Mid-Staffs.html NHS is still gripped by a culture of fear: Inquiry into whistleblowing set up by barrister who investigated Mid Staffs]</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://freedomtospeakup.org.uk/|title=Freedom to Speak Up Review|website=webarchive.nationalarchives.gov.uk|deadurl=bot: unknown|archiveurl=http://webarchive.nationalarchives.gov.uk/20150218150343/https://freedomtospeakup.org.uk/|archivedate=2015-02-18|df=}}</ref> The review was originally expected to report in November 2014 but took longer because of a huge volume of input material: 17,500 online responses and 600 postal responses.<ref>Sophie Borland Daily Mail (21 January 2015) [http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2919200/Probe-NHS-whistleblowers-swamped-18-000-replies.html Probe into NHS whistleblowers is swamped by 18,000 replies: Officials tried to push back report after being deluged with comments by concerned staff]</ref>
The report was published on 11 February 2015.<ref name="Guardian 11Feb2105">{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/society/2015/feb/11/nhs-whistleblowers-report-offers-no-prescription-cover-up-culture |title=NHS whistleblowers report offers no prescription for ending cover-up culture |first=Denis |last=Campbell |work=[[The Guardian]] |date=11 February 2015 |accessdate=9 January 2016}}</ref>
==Recommendations== Francis outlined twenty principles and associated actions, then concluded by making just two recommendations:<ref>{{cite journal |url=http://cri.sagepub.com/content/20/6/128.short |title=Francis’s ‘‘Freedom to Speak Up’’ review: An openness and transparency revolution or just another report? |first=Peter |last=Walsh |journal=Clinical Risk |date= November 2014 |volume=20 |issue=6 |page=128 |doi=10.1177/1356262215575958}}</ref> # for all NHS organisations and regulators to implement all the principles and actions; # for the Secretary of State to review progress annually.
The twenty principles to allow a consistent approach to raising concerns, while still allowing some flexibility, included:<ref name=Parry>Lizzie Parry Daily Mail (11 February 2015) [http://www.dailymail.co.uk/health/article-2948871/NHS-staff-scared-speak-poor-care-Climate-fear-leaves-worried-bullied-lose-job-speak-up.html Climate of fear leaves NHS whistleblowers 'on the brink of suicide' says report but campaigners warn new measures to protect workers 'don't go far enough']</ref> * Culture of raising concerns - to make raising issues a part of normal routine business of any well-led NHS organisation. * Culture free from bullying - freedom of staff to speak out relies on staff being able to work in a culture which is free from bullying. * Training - every member of staff should receive training in their trust's approach to raising concerns and in receiving and acting on them. * Support - all NHS trusts should ensure there is a dedicated person to whom concerns can be easily reported and without formality, a "Freedom to Speak Up Guardian" . * Support to find alternative employment in the NHS - where a worker who has raised a concern cannot, as a result, continue their role, the NHS should help them seek an alternative job.
==Reactions== Many campaigners claimed that the recommendations did not go far enough.<ref name=Parry/><ref>Patrick Sawer, Laura Donnelly The Telegraph (11 February 2015) [https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/health/news/11405430/Whistleblowing-Its-still-not-safe-for-us-to-speak-out.html Whistleblowing: 'It's still not safe for us to speak out']</ref><ref> Sophie Borland, Claire Ellicott, Daniel Martin Daily Mail (12 February 2015) [http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2949934/Whistleblower-whitewash-Health-staff-dare-speak-not-protected-says-report.html Whistleblower whitewash: Health staff who dare to speak out will still not be protected, says report]</ref><ref name="Guardian 11Feb2105"/>
==National Guardian== In January 2016 [[Eileen Sills]] was appointed as the first Freedom to Speak Up National Guardian for the NHS.<ref>[http://www.cqc.org.uk/content/dame-eileen-sills Dame Eileen Sills] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160126120604/http://www.cqc.org.uk/content/dame-eileen-sills |date=2016-01-26 }} [[Care Quality Commission]] website 7 Jan 2016</ref><ref>[http://www.cqc.org.uk/content/cqc-appoints-first-national-guardian-freedom-speak-nhs CQC appoints first National Guardian for the freedom to speak up in the NHS] Care Quality Commission website 7 Jan 2016</ref><ref>[http://www.cqc.org.uk/content/national-freedom-speak-guardian-nhs The National Freedom to Speak Up Guardian for the NHS] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160126122813/http://www.cqc.org.uk/content/national-freedom-speak-guardian-nhs |date=2016-01-26 }} Care Quality Commission website 7 Jan 2016</ref> She resigned two months later, citing that she did not have sufficient time to combine this role with her other work.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/society/2016/mar/08/nhs-national-guardian-resigns-post-eileen-sills|title=NHS's first 'national guardian' resigns after two months|first=Ben|last=Quinn|date=7 March 2016|publisher=|via=The Guardian}}</ref> Dr Henrietta Hughes was appointed as the second Freedom to Speak Up National Guardian in July 2016.<ref>https://www.cqc.org.uk/news/releases/new-national-guardian-appointed-lead-nhs-speaking-freely-safely</ref>

'''GFMS''' (formally Gold Fields Mineral Services)<ref>http://www.business-standard.com/article/markets/jewellery-demand-likely-to-slide-by-8-108041001033_1.html</ref> are research and consultancy company for the [[precious metal]] markets. Since 2011 they have been part of [[Thomson Reuters]]. As well as other commodities, they research [[gold]], [[silver]], [[platinum]], [[palladium]], and [[copper]] trading.
==History== The consultancy’s core publication is the annual ''Gold Survey'', which began in 1967. [[Consolidated Gold Fields]], a mining conglomerate that was later taken over by [[Hanson plc]] in 1989, originally launched the ''Gold Survey''. After the take over, a company was formed the same year to continue the survey.<ref name=hist/>
Between 1994 and 1998, the company was owned by [[Gold Fields|Gold Fields of South Africa]].<ref name=hist/>
Between 1998 and 2003, the company was known as Gold Fields Mineral Services Limited.<ref>https://beta.companieshouse.gov.uk/company/03593787</ref> In 1998, members of the research team completed a management buy out of GFMS from GFSA, and the consultancy gained full independence. In 2002, GFMS became an associate member of the [[London Bullion Market Association]].{{Citation needed|date=April 2017}}
In August 2011, GFMS was purchased by [[Thomson Reuters]].<ref name=hist>{{cite web|url=http://www.gfms.co.uk/?page_id=161|title=Company History|author=|date=|work=|publisher=GFMS|accessdate=6 September 2012|deadurl=bot: unknown|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131016184838/http://www.gfms.co.uk/?page_id=161|archivedate=16 October 2013|df=}}</ref><ref name=tr>http://financial.thomsonreuters.com/en/resources/articles/gfms.html</ref><ref>http://www.stm-publishing.com/thomson-reuters-acquires-uk-based-analyst-firm-gfms/</ref> The execute chairperson [[Philip Klapwijk]] left the company.{{Citation needed|date=April 2017}}
==Business== GFMS analysts present at conferences and seminars on precious metals and commodities. They provide information to the [[news media]].
Their reports include:<ref name=tr /> * ''GFMS Gold Mine Economics'' * ''GFMS Copper Mine Economics'' * ''GFMS Société Générale Global Hedge Book Analysis'' * ''GFMS Société Générale Central Bank Reports'' * ''GFMS Gold Survey'' (annual) * ''World Silver Survey'' (annual) * ''Platinum & Palladium Survey'' (annual) * ''Gold and silver supply/demand benchmark'' * ''GFMS Surveys and Forecasts, and the Mine Economics database'' (provided via the Thomson Reuters Eikon platform)
==Reports== In 2011, GFMS estimated 240 tonnes net sale of gold.<ref>https://www.ft.com/content/cbc02e10-7637-11e0-b4f7-00144feabdc0</ref><ref>http://www.stm-publishing.com/thomson-reuters-acquires-uk-based-analyst-firm-gfms/</ref>
The company estimated that electronic waste recycling increase 14% between 2000 and 2014.<ref>http://www.bullionbulletin.in/more_articles.aspx?pageid=DtErica061115</ref> In 2016, they report a silver supply deficit.<ref>http://www.kitco.com/news/2016-11-17/GFMS-Silver-Market-To-Post-Fourth-Straight-Supply-Deficit-In-2016.html</ref>
In March 2017, GFMS reported that [[India]]'s gold imports had increased to 50 tonnes; 82% higher than 2016.<ref>http://www.business-standard.com/article/economy-policy/gold-imports-surge-to-50-tonnes-on-pent-up-demand-gfms-117030100393_1.html</ref>

'''Graham Fink''' is a <ref>http://www.campaignasia.com/Article/257237,graham-fink-quits-mc-saatchi-london-for-ogilvy-china.aspx</ref> Multimedia artist and Chief Creative Officer at the advertising agency [[Ogilvy & Mather]] China.
Before taking up that appointment in April 2011 he was <ref>http://www.brandrepublic.com/Campaign/News/488673/M-C-Saatchi-hires-Graham-Fink/?DCMP=ILC-BETAMORE</ref> Executive Creative Director at [[M&C Saatchi]] in London. In 1995, he began directing television commercials and music videos at the Paul Weiland film company. Previously, he was Deputy Creative Director at the Gold Greenlees Trott, and Group Head at Saatchi & Saatchi and WCRS. Before that he was an Art Director at CDP. To get this job he dressed up as an old man ( CDP didn't take on junior creatives ). His first job in advertising was as Art Director at Medcalf, Wrightson, Lovelock. All five companies are or were London advertising agencies.
He became the youngest ever President of [[D&AD]] (Design and Art Directors Association) in 1996.<ref>http://www.dandad.org/inspiration/profiles/individuals/graham-fink</ref> He was subsequently voted into [[D&AD]]'s 'Art Direction book' representing the top 28 Art Directors of all time.<ref>http://www.dandad.org/inspiration/profiles/individuals/graham-fink</ref>
He is one of the worlds most awarded creatives having won awards at Cannes, D&AD, One Show, BAFTA, Clio's, LIAA, BTAA, Campaign's UK Big Awards, Creative Circle, Mobius, Eurobest, EPICA, New York Festival, China 4A's, Longxi, SPIKES. In 2011 he won the UK Creative Circle President's Award. And in 2012 he won Ogilvy Asia's first ever Cannes Grand Prix.
His award-winning photography has been used in many advertising campaigns including [[PlayStation]]'s 'Blood' and 'Mental Wealth' poster campaigns. He also directed a short film ( Z ) for the Millennium, commissioned by [[David Puttnam]] which was shortlisted at [[British Academy of Film and Television Arts|BAFTA]].
In 2001 he created <ref>http://www.accessmylibrary.com/coms2/summary_0286-5838960_ITM</ref> thefinktank, a conceptual production company and ideas forum. In 2005 he was awarded a <ref>http://bucks.ac.uk/about/structure/directorates/student_and_academic_services/academic_services/graduation_information/honorary_awards.aspx</ref> Honorary Doctorate at ''[[Bucks New University]]''
In 2014 he had his first one-man exhibition at London's Riflemaker gallery called NOMADS. In 2015 he had his second exhibition in London entitled Drawing with my eyes. For this he drew directly onto a screen using only his eyes via a Tobii eye tracker and software he developed himself with Tobii. http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2015/03/24/graham-fink-eyes_n_6932762.html?1427226337

'''Gérard J. Corboud''' (18 May 1925 – 5 March 2017) was a Swiss entrepreneur, art collector and philanthropist.
From the late-1970s onwards, Corboud and his wife Marisol acquired works by the Impressionists and Post-Impressionists, and later the Neo-Impressionists. In 2001, they made a "permanent loan" of their collection of over 170 works to the [[Wallraf-Richartz Museum]] in [[Cologne]], Germany, which was renamed the Wallraf-Richartz-Museum & Fondation Corboud.<ref name="wallraf1">{{cite web|url=http://www.wallraf.museum/en/the-museum/history/fondation-corboud/ |title=Fondation Corboud: Wallraf-Richartz-Museum |website=Wallraf.museum |date=5 March 2017 |accessdate=14 March 2017}}</ref>
Their collection includes works by Auguste Renoir, Claude Monet, Alfred Sisley, Paul Cézanne, Paul Gauguin and Vincent van Gogh,<ref name="wallraf1"/> and is the largest Impressionist collection in Germany.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hatjecantz.de/masters-of-impressionism-2019-1.html |title=Masters of Impressionism | Classical Modern Art | Hatje Cantz |website=Hatjecantz.de |date=14 January 1945 |accessdate=14 March 2017}}</ref>
Corboud died on 5 March 2017.<ref>{{cite web|author=Martin Oehlen |url=http://www.ksta.de/kultur/kunstsammler-g%C3%A9rard-corboud-mit-91-jahren-gestorben-26146566 |title=Kunstsammler: Gérard Corboud mit 91 Jahren gestorben | Kölner Stadt-Anzeiger |language=de|website=Ksta.de |date=20 January 2017 |accessdate=14 March 2017}}</ref>

{{Multiple issues|{{refimprove|date=September 2012}}{{orphan|date=September 2012}}}}c [[business]] environment; that is, trading and making [[money]] through the exchange of [[foreign currency]]. The international financial activities help the organizations to connect with international dealings with overseas business partners- customers, [[suppliers]], lenders etc. It is also used by [[government]] organization and non-profit institutions.
== History and background ==
During the post-war years, the [[GATT]] was established in order to improve trade. It removed the trade barriers notably over the years, as a result of which international trade grew manifold. The financial participation of the trader's exporters and importers and the international transactions flowed significantly. It started when different countries started “liberalizing” i.e. when countries agreed to open doors for each other and traded. The advancement of technology and liberalization resulted in the idea of financial management both domestically and globally.
== Domestic vs international financial management (IFM)==
Financial Systems may be classified as domestic or overseas, closed or open. A ‘domestic’ is one inside a country. Thus financial system in the {{US}}, is an international financial system from the {{IND}} view. The mean and objective of both domestic and international financial management remains the same but the dimensions and dynamics broaden drastically. Foreign currency, market imperfections, enhanced opportunity sets and political risks are four broader heads under which IFM can be differentiated from financial management (FM).<ref>{{cite web|title=Difference between International and Domestic Financial Management:|url=http://www.efinancemanagement.com/international-financial-management/74-international-financial-management|accessdate=27 September 2012}}</ref> The goal of IFM is not only limited to maximization of [[shareholders]] but also [[stakeholder (corporate)|stakeholder]]s.
== Importance ==
Compared to national financial markets international markets have a different shape and analytics. Proper management of international finances can help the organization in achieving same efficiency and effectiveness in all markets, hence without IFM sustaining in the market can be difficult.
Companies are motivated to invest capital in abroad for the following reasons * Efficiently produce products in [[foreign corporation|foreign]] [[Market (economics)|markets]] than that domestically. * Obtain the essential raw materials needed for production. * Broaden [[Market (economics)|markets]] and diversify * Earn higher returns *foreign investment

The surrounding property had been vacant since JCPenney purchased the land in 1987, to relocate its headquarters to Texas from New York City.Anthony DePalma, [https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/29/nyregion/jc-penney-plans-move-to-dallas-from-new-york-consultants-say.html "Why Penney Is Moving to the Prairies,"] ''[[New York Times]]'', August 23, 1987.Sharon Edelson, [http://wwd.com/business-news/retail/legacy-west-is-bringing-new-brands-to-north-texas-10870904/ "Legacy West Is Bringing New Brands to North Texas,"] ''[[Women's Wear Daily]]'', April 20, 2017. In 2014, JCPenney came to an agreement with local real estate firms Karahan Companies, KDC and Columbus Realty Partners to develop the land. Construction started later that year, with the developers planning a luxury hotel tower, corporate office space, urban shopping center and apartments. When [[Toyota]] announced soon after that it would be moving its North American headquarters to the site from [[Torrance, California]], developers pushed up the timetable for the project.Sean Lester, [https://www.dallasnews.com/business/real-estate/2015/02/03/construction-starting-on-huge-legacy-west-mixed-use-project-in-plano "Construction starting on huge Legacy West mixed-use project in Plano,"] ''Dallas Morning News'', February 3, 2015.Jerry Hirsch, [http://www.latimes.com/business/autos/la-fi-toyota-move-20140429-story.html "3,000 Toyota jobs to move to Texas from Torrance,"] ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'', April 29, 2014.Steve Brown, [https://www.dallasnews.com/business/business/2014/04/29/landing-toyota-headquarters-has-pushed-up-the-timetable-for-planos-legacy-west-project "Landing Toyota headquarters has pushed up the timetable for Plano's Legacy West project,"] ''Dallas Morning News'', April 29, 2014. Toyota broke ground to begin construction on its new $350 million 100-acre headquarters in January 2015.Catherine Ross, [http://www.nbcdfw.com/news/local/Planos-Legacy-West-Booming-as-Toyota-Breaks-Ground-289205581.html "Plano's 'Legacy West' Booming as Toyota Breaks Ground,"] [[NBC Dallas]], January 20, 2015. The following month, developers broke ground on the first phase of Legacy West's $2 billion mixed-use project. Construction continued over the next two years on corporate offices, residential, retail, and restaurant properties. On June 2, 2017, Legacy West officially opened the shopping district to the public. [[Secretary_of_State_of_Texas|Secretary of State of Texas]] [[Rolando Pablos]], [[Mayor_of_Plano,_Texas|Plano Mayor]] [[Harry LaRosiliere]] and developer Fehmi Karahan helped cut the ceremonial ribbon for the grand opening.Steve Brown, [https://www.dallasnews.com/business/real-estate/2017/06/02/plano-celebrates-opening-legacy-west-urban-village "Plano officially opens Legacy West urban village: 'Welcome to the center of the universe',"] ''Dallas Morning News'', June 2, 2017. In late 2017 construction continued on projects anchoring the northern end of the retail and entertainment district, including Legacy Hall, a three-story food hall that will have more than two-dozen stalls featuring food concepts from restaurateurs including Dallas-based chef John Tesar and [[Chili's]] founder Larry Lavine.Gavin Pugh, [https://communityimpact.com/guides/dallas-fort-worth/plano/news/commerce/2017/10/27/legacy-hall-opening-date-moved-plus-3-other-updates-about-planos-legacy-west/ "Legacy Hall opening date moved, plus 3 other updates about Plano's Legacy West,"] ''Community Impact'', October 27, 2017.Daniel Rockey, [http://planomagazine.com/legacy-hall/ "Legacy Hall,"] ''Plano Magazine'', October 30, 2017. Legacy Hall will also house a brewery and tap room from Unlawful Assembly Brewing Company.Karen Robinson-Jacobs, [https://www.dallasnews.com/business/restaurants/2017/10/20/coming-new-food-hall-planos-legacy-west "Here's what's coming to the new food hall at Plano's Legacy West,"] ''Dallas Morning News'', October 20, 2017. ==Shops, hotel and tenants== [[Image:Legacy West Plano Texas 2017.png|thumb|right|Legacy West at the entry to Windrose Avenue, June 2017.]] All of the restaurants and retailers are located on tree-lined Windrose Avenue, which spans from [[Sam Rayburn Tollway]] to Legacy Drive, where it ends at the [[Beal Bank]] corporate office. MAria Halkias and KAren Robinson-Jacobs[https://www.dallasnews.com/business/retail/2016/12/29/massive-legacy-west-project-prepares-march-opening "A peek at the restaurants, stores you'll find when Plano's massive Legacy West opens in March"] ''[[Dallas Morning News]]'', January 27, 2017. Shops include [[Coach, Inc|Coach]], [[Bonobos (apparel)|Bonobos]], [[Fabletics]], a [[Tesla, Inc.|Tesla]] showroom, [[Warby Parker]], [[Levi's]], [[MAC Cosmetics]], [[J.Crew]], [[Sephora]], [[Tumi Inc.|Tumi]], [[Filson (company)|Filson]], Peter Millar and [[West Elm]]. There is also a [[Barnes & Noble]] concept store with a restaurant serving wine and beerCandace Carlisle, [https://www.bizjournals.com/dallas/news/2016/09/01/barnes-noble-bringing-the-beer-wine-and-books-to.html "Barnes & Noble bringing the beer, wine and books to Plano's Legacy West,"] ''[[Dallas Business Journal]]'', September 1, 2016. and a [[Tommy Bahama]] Island store and restaurant, in addition to [[Del Frisco's Double Eagle Steak House]], [[Shake Shack]], True Food Kitchen, Taverna and [[Starbucks|Starbucks Reserve]]. At the center of the development is a 3,500 square-foot [[Bellagio (resort)|Bellagio]]-inspired fountain where choreographed water, light and music shows take place. Legacy West is home to the headquarters of [[JCPenney]],Gensler, [https://www.gensler.com/projects/legacy-west "Legacy West"] January 27, 2018.Peter Grant,[https://legacywest.com/2017/01/18/j-c-penney-sets-trend-in-reviving-suburban-corporate-campuses/ "J.C. Penney Sets Trend in Reviving Suburban Corporate Campuses"] ''Wall Street Journal'', January 27, 2018. [[FedEx Office]],Ben Russell, [https://www.nbcdfw.com/news/local/Planos-Massive-Legacy-West-Development-Opens-Friday-425892523.html "Plano's Massive Legacy West Development Opens Friday,"] NBC Dallas, June 2, 2017. [[NTT Data#History|NTT Data Systems]],Steve Brown,[https://www.dallasnews.com/business/real-estate/2017/06/26/ntt-data-adding-office-planos-3-billion-legacy-west NTT Data adding offices to Plano for 3 billion at Legacy West], [[Dallas Morning News]], January 28, 2018. and [[Fogo de Chão]] Karen Robinson, [https://www.dallasnews.com/business/business/2016/11/30/fogo-de-cho-plans-north-texas-expansion-uptown-plano "Fogo de Chão plans North Texas expansion to Uptown, Plano"] ''Dallas News'', June 4, 2018. and the North American headquarters for [[Toyota Motor Corporation]], and the regional headquarters for [[JPMorgan Chase]],Steve Brown, [https://www.dallasnews.com/business/real-estate/2017/04/26/chases-300-million-legacy-west-project-tops "Chase's $300 million Legacy West project in Plano tops out,"] ''Dallas Morning News'', April 26, 2017. and [[Liberty Mutual Insurance]].Candace Carlisle, [https://www.bizjournals.com/dallas/news/2017/04/06/liberty-mutual-reaches-milestone-on-325m-campus-in.html "Liberty Mutual reaches milestone on $325M campus in Plano's Legacy West,"] ''Dallas Business Journal'', April 6, 2017. It also includes the 15-story, 303-room [[Renaissance Hotels|Renaissance Dallas at Plano Legacy West Hotel]].Lily Corral, [https://www.dmagazine.com/commercial-real-estate/2017/07/legacy-west-hotel-opens-its-doors/ "Legacy West Hotel Opens Its Doors,"] ''[[D Magazine]]'', July 10, 2017. ==The Shops at Legacy== To the east of Legacy West and [[Dallas North Tollway]] is the Shops at Legacy, a [[lifestyle center]] that opened in 2002 and has 33 stores. It is located south of the corporate headquarters of [[Alliance Data]] and [[LegacyTexas Bank]].[http://shopsatlegacy.com/shops/shopping Shopping]The Shops at Legacy, January 28, 2017. The Shops at Legacy has a luxury [[Marriot International|Marriot]] hotel called the Dallas/Plano Marriott at Legacy Town Center just south of Legacy Drive, overlooking Bishop Park and houses [[Hilti#Hilti North America (HNA)|Hilti North America]], Hilti's North American headquarters.[http://www.marriott.com/hotels/travel/dalpt-dallas-plano-marriott-at-legacy-town-center/?scid=bb1a189a-fec3-4d19-a255-54ba596febe2 Dallas/Plano Marriott at Legacy Town Center][[Marriot International]], January 28, 2017. Right in the center of The Shops at Legacy is the Baccus Cemetery, the oldest cemetery in Plano dating back to about 1847 where Captain Henry Cook buried his son Daniel Cook, a veteran from the [[War of 1812]]. The Baccus Cemetery is one of the most historic sites in Plano.Candace Fountoulakis,[http://planomagazine.com/baccus-cemetery/ Baccus Cemetery]Plano Magazine, January 28, 2017. Shops include [[Benefit Cosmetics]], [[bluemercury]], [[Elaine Turner#Business|Elaine Turner]], [[Kendra Scott#Kendra Scott, LLC|Kendra Scott]], [[Lululemon Athletica|lululemon athletica]], and [[Urban Outfitters]].{{Cite web|url=http://shopsatlegacy.com/shops/shopping|title=SHOPPING|date=June 4, 2018}} ==See also== * [[Plano, Texas]] * [[List of shopping malls in Texas]] ==References== {{reflist|colwidth=30em}} ==External links== * [http://www.legacywest.com/ Official website] {{Plano, Texas}} [[Category:Buildings and structures in Plano, Texas]] [[Category:Tourist attractions in Texas]] [[Category:Shopping malls in the Dallas–Fort Worth metroplex]] [[Category:Central business districts in the United States]]

{{EngvarB|date=July 2016}} {{Use dmy dates|date=July 2016}} '''NewMusicSA''' is the South African section of the [[International Society for Contemporary Music]] (ISCM). Its formation on 10 May 1999 heralded the return of South African representation at the ISCM after many decades.Blake 2007.Heuvelmans 2000. == Nature and Purpose == NewMusicSA is a non-profit organisation which supports the creation and performance of New Music by South African composers of all stylistic and cultural backgrounds. The organisation holds annual new music festivals, commissions works, puts out calls for scores and runs the South African New Music Ensemble. It publishes the NewMusicSA Bulletin, an annual periodical offering articles on current New Music events, issues, composers and performers, together with scores of recent works by South African composers. It provides information services for current events in the form of its monthly newsletter, and aims to foster collaboration and a sense of community among its members and the wider New Music community. == Annual Festival == Since 2000, the organisation has held an annual festival, the New Music Indaba, which showcases contemporary South African music performed by musicians based both within the country and abroad. A central part of the festival are the 'Growing Composers' workshops, which provide the opportunity for emerging composers to work with established musicians and composers in a supportive environment. From 2000 to 2006, the New Music Indaba was held as part of the National Arts Festival in [[Grahamstown]] in the [[Eastern Cape]] province. From 2007 to 2009 the festival was hosted by the [[University of South Africa]] (UNISA) in Pretoria/Tshwane, Gauteng. {{Infobox music festival | name =Unyazi Electronic Music Festival | image = | caption = | location =Johannesburg and Durban | years_active = | founders = | dates = | genre = [[Electronic music]], | attendance = | capacity = | website = }} NewMusicSA also runs the '''Unyazi Electronic Music Festival''', which alternates with the New Music Indaba on an annual basis. Since 2010 the two festivals have been hosted variously in Johannesburg and Durban. The 2014 Unyazi Electronic Music Festival was held in Johannesburg, hosted by the University of the Witwatersrand School of Arts. Other notable projects include [[The Bow Project]], which commissioned numerous composers to write new pieces for string quartet based on the uhadi bow music of [[Nofinishi Dywili]]. == Exchange Programmes and Collaborations == NewMusicSA has provided an important link between South African art music composers and the international contemporary art music community by means of an exchange programme with the Visby International Centre for Composers (VICC). This programme has provided residencies for numerous South African composers in [[Gotland]], Sweden. The most recent call for applicants took place in 2014, the residencies being awarded to Samora Ntsebeza and Pierre-Henri Wicomb. Since its foundation, NewMusicSA has worked with a number of other South African music and cultural organisations, such as the [[Southern African Music Rights Organisation]] (SAMRO), the Unisa Music Foundation and most recently the [[South African National Youth Orchestra Foundation|South African National Youth Orchestra]] to provide opportunities for emerging South African composers. In 2008 the archive of NewMusicSA, which includes much documentary information and numerous unique music scores by South African composers was donated to the Documentation Centre for Music at the [[University of Stellenbosch]] in the Western Cape province. == ISCM World Music Days Festival == An important aspect of the organisation's role is to convene an annual jury to select South African works that will be considered for performance at the ISCM's World Music Days festival. South African composers whose works have been selected for performance at the World Music Days Festival by the ISCM's international jury in recent years include, [[Robert Fokkens]] (2009), Clare Loveday (2008) and [[Stefans Grové]] (2007). In the past the music of [[Bongani Ndodana-Breen]], [[Kevin Volans]], Hans Huyssen, Mokale Koapeng, [[Hendrik Hofmeyr]], [[Jürgen Bräuninger]] has also been heard at the festival. The 2015 festival will see the performance of another South African work. == South African New Music Ensemble == In 2013 NewMusicSA founded the South African New Music Ensemble (SANME), a chamber ensemble of variable instrumentation formulated with the purpose of bringing together performers and composers of new music in South Africa. The ensemble played its debut performance at the 2013 New Music Indaba at the University of KwaZulu-Natal Howard College Campus. In the same year NewMusicSA issued its first commissions in a call for scores for two works to be played by the ensemble. The call was for one entirely instrumental/acoustic work and one mixed electronic/acoustic work. The acoustic commission was awarded to Pierre-Henri Wicomb. The electronic/acoustic commission was awarded to Maxim Starcke. == Board and Past presidents == The board members as of 2014 are: Mr Chris Jeffery – Chair
Mr Douglas Scott – Treasurer
Mr William Fourie – Secretary & Vice-Chair
Dr Chris van Rhyn – Bulletin co-Editor
Mr Lukas Ligeti – Bulletin co-Editor
Mr Malcolm Dedman – Communications & Membership officer
Dr Cameron Harris – Board member
Ms Fiona Tozer – Board member Past presidents of NewMusicSA include [[Michael Blake (composer)|Michael Blake]] (who founded the organisation), Mokale Koapeng, Christopher Walton, Cameron Harris and Angie Mullins. ==See also== {{Commons category|NewMusicSA}} *[[List of electronic music festivals]] == References == {{Reflist}} == Sources == * Blake, M. 2007. 'South African Composers on the World Stage: The ISCM in South Africa’ in Fontes Artis Musicae 54/3 July–September 2007. 359–73. * Heuvelmans, H. 2000. ‘Minutes of the ISCM General Assembly 1999 in Bucharest’ in World New Music. 10. September 2001. == External links == * {{Official website|http://www.newmusicsa.org.za/}} * [http://www.iscm.org/ International Society for Contemporary Music] * [http://www.newmusicsa.org.za/unyazi-2014 Unyazi Electronic Music Festival 2014] * [http://www.newmusicsa.org.za/bowproject2009.html The Bow Project] * [http://www.domus.ac.za/component/option,com_frontpage/Itemid,1/ Documentation Centre for Music] ([https://lib.sun.ac.za/jspui/handle/10019.2/390?mode=full DOMUS]) [[Category:South African music]] [[Category:New music organizations]] [[Category:Business organisations based in South Africa]] [[Category:Organizations established in 1999]]

'''Power to the edge''' refers to the ability of an organization to dynamically synchronize its actions; achieve [[Command and control (military)|command and control]] (C2) agility; and increase the speed of command over a robust, networked grid. The term is most commonly used in relation to military organizations, but it can equally be used in a civilian context.
"Power to the edge" is an information and organization management philosophy first articulated by the U.S. Department of Defense in a publication by Dr. [[David S. Alberts]] and Richard E. Hayes in 2003 titled: "Power to the Edge: Command...Control...in the Information Age." This book was published by the [[Command and Control Research Program]] and can be downloaded from the [http://www.dodccrp.org/ Program's website].
==Principles== Power to the edge advocates the following:
*Achieving situational awareness rather than creating a single operational picture *Self-synchronizing operations instead of autonomous operations *Information "pull" rather than broadcast information "push" *Collaborative efforts rather than individual efforts *Communities of Interest (COIs) rather than stovepipes *"Task, post, process, use" rather than "task, process, exploit, disseminate" *Handling information once rather than handling multiple data calls *Sharing data rather than maintaining private data *Persistent, continuous information assurance rather than perimeter, one-time security *Bandwidth on demand rather than bandwidth limitations *IP-based transport rather than circuit-based transport *Net-Ready KPP rather than interoperability KPP *Enterprise services rather than separate infrastructures *COTS based, net-centric capabilities rather than customized, platform-centric IT
==Agility== The philosophy of power to the edge is aimed at achieving organizational agility. Such agility has six attributes:
*Robustness: the ability to maintain effectiveness across a range of tasks, situations, and conditions *Resilience: the ability to recover from or adjust to misfortune, damage, or a destabilizing perturbation in the environment *Responsiveness: the ability to react to a change in the environment in a timely manner *Flexibility: the ability to employ multiple ways to succeed and the capacity to move seamlessly between them *Innovation: the ability to do new things and the ability to do old things in new ways *Adaptation: the ability to change work processes and the ability to change the organization
==See also== *[[Network-centric organization]] *[[Network-centric warfare]] *[[Network simulator]]
==External links== *[[Command and Control Research Program]]
==References== *[http://www.dodccrp.org/ Command and Control Research Program Website] *[http://www.dodccrp.org/files/Alberts_Power.pdf Power to the Edge] by Alberts and Hayes (2003) *[http://www.chips.navy.mil/archives/02_Summer/authors/index2_files/power_to_the_edge.htm Power to the Edge] presentation by Dr. Margaret Myers, CIO-DOD *[http://www.afrlhorizons.com/Briefs/Feb05/IF0409.html "Command and Control Implications of Network-Centric Warfare"]

{{more citations needed|date=July 2017}} '''Santiago Bilinkis''' is a entrapreneur and technologist. As a businessperson, he was co-founder and CEO of [[Officenet]], the largest office supplies dealer in Argentina and Brazil, acquired by [[Staples Inc.]] in 2004. A case called "[https://cb.hbsp.harvard.edu/cbmp/product/800238-PDF-ENG Officenet: how to make entrepreneurship work in Argentina]" was written by [[Harvard Business School]] and taught at over 25 universities. He also co-founded several other companies, including [[Behaviour Santiago|Wanako Games]], [https://restorando.com/ Restorando], and Trocafone. Santiago is now a Founding Partner at [http://www.quasarbuilders.com/ Quasar Builders], a tech company builder. He is very active in the non-profit sector as well, having served as a Board member to NGOs such as [http://www.endeavor.org/ Endeavor], [http://www.cippec.org/ CIPPEC] and [http://chequeado.com/ Chequeado].
He is the author of the blog [http://bilinkis.com/ Riesgo y Recompensa], one of the most popular on Technology and Entrepreneurship in Latin America. His first book “[http://libro.bilinkis.com/ Pasaje al futuro]” was launched by [[Penguin Random House]] in November 2014 and is already on its fourth edition.
As a technologist, he was selected in 2010 to attend [[Singularity University]] in a NASA base in Silicon Valley, where he could learn from the most notable scientists and business leaders in areas such as [[Artificial intelligence|Artificial Intelligence]], [[Robotics]], [[Biotechnology|Biotech]], [[Nanotechnology|Nanotech]] and [[Neuroscience]].
As a science and technology communicator, he is co-host of a radio show at "Basta de todo", one of the most widely heard in Argentina and writes a column for “[[La Nación]]” newspaper. In 2013 he was featured on the [[Discovery Channel]] documentary "2111", together with notable futurists [[Ray Kurzweil]], [[James Canton]] and [[Aubrey de Grey]]. The City of Buenos Aires awarded him as a “Notable Citizen in Science and Technology”.
As a keynote speaker, he gave numerous speeches at universities such as [[MIT Sloan School of Management]] and [[Harvard Business School]], and for many companies and governmental entities. Santiago was one of the organizers of the first [http://www.tedx-buenosaires.org/ TEDxBuenosAires] and is currently organizing [http://www.tedxriodelaplata.org/ TEDxRiodelaPlata].
Santiago graduated with Gold Medal in Economics at [http://www.udesa.edu.ar/ San Andrés University].
== External links ==

'''Sean Mulryan''' (born September 1954) is an Irish<ref name=Telegraph>''Telegraph'': [https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/1528481/Revealed-the-reclusive-property-mogul-who-has-already-won-the-Olympics.html Revealed: the reclusive property mogul who has already won the Olympics], accessdate: 1 September 2014</ref> property developer, and the founder and chairman and CEO of the [[Ballymore Group]], a Dublin-based international property development company. He was named on the [[Estates Gazette]] 2017 'Power List', which lists the 50 most powerful individuals in Britain's commercial real estate sector. Mulryan was the only Irish person to be named on the list, which included US Billionaire and [[Amazon.com|Amazon]] founder [[Jeff Bezos]] and the Chairman of [[C C Land|CC Land]], Cheung Chung Kiu.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.independent.ie/business/commercial-property/mulryan-joins-jeff-bezos-on-uk-property-power-list-35875057.html|title=Mulryan joins Jeff Bezos on UK property 'power list' |work=The Irish Independent|access-date=10 July 2017}}</ref>
==Early life== Sean Mulryan was born in September 1954,<ref name=CH>{{cite web|title=BALLYMORE LIMITED|url=https://beta.companieshouse.gov.uk/company/04936525/officers|website=Companies House|accessdate=29 July 2015}}</ref> the son of John and Josephine Mulryan.<ref name=Telegraph/> He grew up in rural poverty in the village of Oran, near [[Castlerea]], Co Roscommon,<ref name=Telegraph/><ref name=SC/> in the west of Ireland, in a farming family with seven children.<ref name=HP>''Homes & Property'': [http://www.homesandproperty.co.uk/property-news/news/sean-mulryan-man-who-owns-land-every-corner-london Sean Mulryan: the man who owns land in every corner of Londo], accessdate: 1 September 2014</ref>
Mulryan left school at the age of 17, and trained as a bricklayer. Aged 19, he bought his first plot of land.<ref name=HP/> At 26 he set up his own company and shortly afterwards founded Ballymore, which is now considered one Europe's biggest property developers.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.roscommonpeople.ie/archive/55-archives/at-home-with-sean-mulryan|title=At home with Sean Mulryan – Roscommon People – The People's Paper|last=People|first=Roscommon|access-date=7 February 2017}}</ref>
==Ballymore Group== Ballymore Group was founded in 1982 by Mulryan, then aged 28, who is the chairman. David Brophy is the group chief executive.<ref name=PR>prnewswire.co.uk: [http://www.prnewswire.co.uk/news-releases/ballymore-announces-group-reorganisation-152879555.html Ballymore Announces Group Reorganisation – DUBLIN, July 3 /PR Newswire UK/ --], accessdate: 30 August 2014</ref>
Ballymore has become one of the biggest providers of residential space in London.<ref name=IrishTimes>irishtimes.com: [http://www.irishtimes.com/life-and-style/homes-and-property/the-irish-developer-with-a-big-vision-for-london-1.2284778 The Irish developer with a big vision for London --]</ref> In 2017, it was reported that the previous year's profits at the UK arm of Ballymore had increased almost three-fold to £154.9m (€217.6m).<ref name=Independent>independent.ie: [http://www.independent.ie/business/irish/exceptional-gains-push-sean-mulryans-ballymore-uk-profits-to-217m-34342258.html Exceptional gains push Sean Mulryan's Ballymore UK profits to €217m --]</ref>
Ballymore Group works on large-scale projects in London and across Europe, with a particular focus on urban regeneration.
In 2016, it was reported that Oran native Sean Mulryan launched the latest development in Dublin, which is a €700 million development in the docklands.<ref name=RoscommonDaily>roscommondaily.com: [http://roscommondaily.com/2016/10/oran-native-700m-ballymore/ Oran native launches €700m Ballymore development --]</ref>
Several members of the Mulryan family have been involved in Ballymore. John Mulryan is a son of Sean Mulryan and the managing director of Ballymore UK, meanwhile, Sean's brother Donal Mulryan used to work for Ballymore before starting his own development company, West Properties, which owns various developments in the UK, including Skyline Central, the tallest apartment complex in Manchester.<ref name=IrishTimes2>irishtimes.com: [http://www.irishtimes.com/business/commercial-property/docklands-project-brings-ballymore-back-to-centre-stage-1.2819321 Docklands project brings Ballymore back to centre stage --]</ref><ref name=BDCMagazine>bdcmagazine.com: [http://www.bdcmagazine.com/building-news/construction-news/housing/8744-8744 Featuring Ballymore: Interview With Sean Mulryan (Chairman & Group Chief Executive) --]</ref>
As of 2012, he is one of the richest men in Ireland.<ref name=HP/> According to London's ''[[The Evening Standard]]'', Mulryan owns more land in London than the [[Gerald Grosvenor, 6th Duke of Westminster|Duke of Westminster]].<ref name=HP/>
On 16 February 2012, Wandsworth Council approved [[Ballymore Group]]'s plans for the 15 acre development in [[Nine Elms]]. [[Embassy Gardens]] is set to provide "up to 1,982 new homes alongside shops, cafes, bars, restaurants, business space, a 100 bed hotel, a health centre, children's playgrounds and sports pitches".<ref name=Wandsworth>Wandsworth Council: [http://www.wandsworth.gov.uk/news/article/11030/embassy_gardens_plans_approved Embassy Gardens plans approved | Wandsworth Council], accessdate: 9 September 2014</ref> In 2014, it was reported that Mulryan had engaged [[Lazard]] and [[CBRE Group]] to raise about €2.5bn to fund the Embassy Gardens development.<ref name=Independent.ie>Independent.ie: [http://www.independent.ie/business/irish/nick-webb-mulryan-is-close-to-wiping-slate-clean-30301129.html Nick Webb: Mulryan is close to wiping slate clean], accessdate: 1 September 2014</ref>
Outside of his work with Ballymore, Mulryan is set to join the board of the Ireland West Airport Knock in 2017.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Quinlan|first1=Ronald|title=Knock Airport to bring Ballymore's Mulryan on board|url=http://www.independent.ie/business/irish/knock-airport-to-bring-ballymores-mulryan-on-board-35687591.html|website=The Irish Independent|accessdate=16 May 2017}}</ref> Knock confirmed the appointment in May 2017, along with two other new Directors. The airport is considered key for regional development and it expects to handle around 750,000 passengers in 2017, making it its busiest year.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/business/transport-and-tourism/sean-mulryan-joins-knock-airport-board-1.3103015|title=Sean Mulryan joins Knock Airport board|work=The Irish Times|access-date=2 June 2017}}</ref>
==Personal life== Mulryan and his wife Bernadine live at the [[Ardenode Stud]], County Kildare, with five children. They are very active in horse racing and own "somewhere between 50 and 100" racehorses, trained in Ireland and France.<ref name=Telegraph/><ref name=SC>Shopping Centre: [http://www.shopping-centre.co.uk/news/archivestory.php/aid/1135/Mulryan_of_many_talents.html Mulryan of many talents], accessdate: 1 September 2014</ref> Among his top horses was Forget the Past, which was a multiple winner at the highest level over jumps and trained by Michael O’Brien, who handled a number of Mulryan-owned horses. He also owned flat horses, including Thewayyouare, which was once considered to be a strong contender for [[Epsom Derby|The Derby]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/business/construction/ballymore-puts-the-building-boom-back-into-horse-racing-1.3047540|title=Ballymore puts the building boom back into horse racing|work=The Irish Times|access-date=8 May 2017}}</ref> In 2017, Mulryan's Ballymore Properties sponsored the headline race on the last day of the [[Punchestown Racecourse|Punchestown]] National Hunt Festival. Worth over €100,000, the Ballymore Handicap Hurdle is run over two and a half miles and is one of the most hotly contested races of the festival.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.kildare-nationalist.ie/2017/04/20/naas-all-set-for-punchestown/|title=Kildare Nationalist – Naas all set for Punchestown|access-date=8 May 2017}}</ref>
His friends include the athlete and politician [[Seb Coe]] and [[Bono]], the singer in the Irish pop group [[U2]]. [[Debbie Harry]], of the pop group [[Blondie (band)|Blondie]] sang at his 50th birthday party.<ref name="Telegraph" />

[[Coleg Glan Hafren]] | occupation = Entrepreneur | years_active = 1991–present | employer = | organization = | agent = | known_for = | notable_works = | style = [[Frozen food]] | influences = | influenced = | home_town = | salary = | net_worth = {{increase}} [[£]] 80 million | height = | weight = | television = | title = Chairman and Managing Director of [[Euro Foods (UK)]] | term = | predecessor = | successor = | party = | movement = | opponents = | boards = | denomination = | children = | spouse = Bobi Hussain | relatives = | callsign = | awards = | module = | website = {{URL|eurofoods.co.uk}} | footnotes = | box_width = }} '''Shelim Hussain''', [[Member of the Order of the British Empire|MBE]] (born 20 February 1973) is a Bangladeshi-born British entrepreneur, and founder, chairman and managing director of [[Euro Foods (UK)|Euro Foods]]. ==Early life== Hussain was born in [[Bangladesh]] and was brought to the United Kingdom by his uncle and aunt in 1985. After a year of living in London his uncle moved to [[Cardiff]] in 1986{{cite news|last=|first=|url=http://www.redhotcurry.com/food_and_drink/other/shelim_hussain.htm|title=Food Entrepreneur Wins AOC Gold Award|work=|location=|publisher=''Redhotcurry.com''|date=5 June 2005|accessdate=6 January 2008|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080207172850/http://www.redhotcurry.com/food_and_drink/other/shelim_hussain.htm|archivedate=7 February 2008|df=dmy-all}} when he was 11{{cite news |last=Henry|first=Graham|url=http://www.walesonline.co.uk/business/business-news/recession-nets-550000-windfall-firm-1889661|title=Recession nets £550,000 windfall for firm|work= |location=Wales|publisher=''Wales Online''|date=6 October 2010|accessdate=1 November 2014}} and he was enrolled at [[List of places in Cardiff#Cathays|Cathays High School]]. ==Career== At the age of 17, Hussain started working as a waiter at the Indian Ocean restaurant in [[Gabalfa]]. Around 1991, at the age of 18, when the local prawn supplier went out of business, having seen a gap in the market, Hussain took £20 worth of fuel and the money to buy six cases of prawns – and sold them on. He started his business while working evenings as a part-time as a waiter in the restaurant and studying at college for his [[GCE Advanced Level (United Kingdom)|A Levels]] at [[Coleg Glan Hafren]]. He saw an opportunity in the market for [[prawn]] supply and started off by selling a few boxes of frozen prawns with his friend, delivering them at night while continuing with his education during the day. He started the business with an initial capital of only £20. The annual turnover for his business is around £80 million as of 2010.{{cite book |last1=Karim|first1=Mohammed Abdul|last2=Karim|first2=Shahadoth|title=British Bangladeshi Who's Who|url=http://www.bbwhoswho.co.uk/whoswho_09.pdf|date=October 2009|publisher=British Bangla Media Group|page=64|isbn= |accessdate=1 May 2012}} ===Euro Foods (UK)=== In 1993, Hussain formed [[Euro Foods (UK)]] and the company has grown rapidly since. He employs over 200 staff and has food processing units in [[Newport, Wales|Newport]], [[Barking, London|Barking]] and [[Sunderland, Tyne and Wear|Sunderland]].{{cite news |last= |first= |url=http://www.insidermedia.com/insider/midlands/101355-wolverhampton-hub-boosts-euro-foods/|title=Wolverhampton hub boosts Euro Foods|work= |location=Wales|publisher=''Insider Media Limited''|date=25 October 2013|accessdate=1 November 2014}} Hussain is the chief executive of Newport-based Euro Foods which has an annual turnover of £80m, as well as a £20m subsidiary empire in Asia. He also has a new plant and four factories in [[Bangladesh]], and has started a subsidiary in New York City. He also has invested in property development business in [[Wales]]. At present he is founder, chairman and managing director of the following companies: Euro Foods (UK) Ltd, S & B Developments Ltd, SRS Poultry Ltd (commencing late 2003), Eurasia Food Processing (BD) Ltd (Bangladesh), Euro, Linen Service (UK) Ltd, Horizon Seafood Ltd, Saidowla Enterprise, Euro Foods (BD) Ltd & Rosemco foods Ltd (BD). All of factory setup by latest machine and as per HACCP rule. ==Awards and recognition== In 2003, Hussain was appointed a [[Member of the Order of the British Empire]] (MBE) in the [[2003 New Year Honours]] for his services to business in Wales.{{cite news |last= |first= |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/wales/2990606.stm|title=Welsh birthday honours list|work= |location= |publisher=''[[BBC News]]''|date=14 June 2003|accessdate=11 May 2007}} In 2003, he won the ''[[Eastern Eye (newspaper)|Eastern Eye]]'' Young Achiever Award that was presented by [[Charles, Prince of Wales|Prince Charles, The Prince of Wales]], and he was nominated for Young Achiever at the Asian Jewel Awards. In 2005, he won the AoC Gold Award for Further Education Alumni. In 2011, he was awarded the Personality of the Year at the [[The British Curry Awards|British Curry Awards]], presented on video message by [[David Cameron]].{{Cite news |last= |first= |url=http://www.thisislocallondon.co.uk/news/9391355.Cream_of_curry_industry_gather_for_British_Curry_Awards/|title=Cream of curry industry gather for British Curry Awards|work= |location=London|publisher=''[[This Is Local London]]''|date=30 November 2011|accessdate=30 November 2011}} ==See also== * [[British Bangladeshi]] * [[Business of British Bangladeshis]] * [[List of British Bangladeshis]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.eurofoods.co.uk Eurofoods wholesale food suppliers website] {{DEFAULTSORT:Hussain, Shelim}} [[Category:1973 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:British Muslims]] [[Category:Bangladeshi emigrants to Wales]] [[Category:Naturalised citizens of the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Bangladeshi businesspeople]] [[Category:British businesspeople]] [[Category:People from Newport, Wales]] [[Category:Members of the Order of the British Empire]]
